Catalyst preparation and activity studies A.F. Ahlstrom-Sllversanda' , C.U. Ingemar Odenbrandb aKatator AB, Ideon Research Park, Ole R6mers viig 12, S-223 70, Lund, Sweden bDepartment of Chemical Engineering II, Chemical Center, Lund Universi~, Institute of Science and Technology, PO. Box 124, S-221 00, Lund, Sweden Received 4 June 1996: received in revised form 9 September 1996; accepted 10 September 1996 Abstract Catalytically active wire meshes were used to combust different pollutants present in flue gases from bio-fuel combustion, e.g. CO, propylene, terpenes and tar. Alumina was spray-deposited onto wire meshes of Kanthal AF (8-20 Tayler mesh) with a plasma spray equipment. The specific surface area of the ceramic layer was increased through wash coating, in-situ precipitation or sol-treatment. The catalytically active materials consisted of precious metals (Pd/Pt) or metal oxides (V2Os/CuO) and were added to the ceramic matrix through an impregnation technique. The combustion was in most cases severely limited by external mass transfer. The effects of the specific surface area and the loading of catalytically active material were only significant in the reaction controlled domain. In the mass transfer controlled domain the conversion was affected only by the flow conditions and the external surface area of the wire meshes. CO and most hydrocarbons were effectively combusted at temperatures below 773 on a Pd/Pt-catalyst. The catalyst performance was not affected by the presence of water vapour or carbon dioxide or by low oxygen concentrations. Similar combustion experiments were performed with a commercial monolith and it can be concluded that the performance of the catalytically active wire meshes in the mass-transfer controlled domain was superior. Tar-residues, soot particulates and charcoal particles were effectively combusted over a Pd/Pt-doped oxide-catalyst (V2OflCuO). Introduction Small-scale combustion of bio-fuel often results in excesswe emissions of volatile organic compounds (VOC), polyaromatic compounds (PAH) and carbon monoxide (CO). These compounds have a negative impact on human health and urban air quality. Some of the VOC- and PAH-compounds are highly toxic or carcinogenic, e.g. benzene and benzo(a)pyrene [1]. The predominant volatile organic compounds present in flue gases from bio-fuel combustion are propylene, ethylene, butadiene, methanol, ethanol, methane, phenol and benzene. Propylene alone stands for approximately 30% of the total VOC-emission from small-scale combustion of bio-fuel. There is a tendency towards an increased utilisation of bio-fuel in the society due to the negative effects caused by fossil fuel combustion, i.e. the green house effect and the consumption of irreplaceable global resources. Bio-fuel is considered as a renewable energy source which does not contribute to the net emission of carbon dioxide. The positive attributes of bio-fuels may however be deteriorated by the excessive emissions of CO, VOC and PAH during combustion. Wood combustion is characterised by three phases: drying, pyrolysis and charcoal combustion. The drying process occurs at around 100 and involves the release of physically and chemically bound water. The water content of wood normally lies between 10 and 60 wt.%. Pyrolysis involves the formation and release of hydrocarbons with a high heat-content. These hydrocarbons are nor- mally combusted in the stove but some may be emitted to the atmosphere. Thermogravimetfic analysis shows that different components of the wood are pyrolysed at different temperatures (hemi-cellulose at 200-260, cellulose at 240-350 and lignin at 280-500) [2]. Approximately 80% of the wood is normally pyrolysed. The residue, mainly derived from the lignin content, produces charcoal. Charcoal combustion requires temperatures in the region of 900 to be completed. The ultimate residue after a completed combustion cycle is ash, corresponding to 1 wt.% or less of the initial wood weight (on dry basis). The ash mainly consist of alkaline and alkaline earth metal oxides. The poor combustion performance of some wood stoves has in certain cases led to legislation against small-scale combustion of bio-fuel in urban areas. Re- construction of the stoves may in some cases improve the combustion performance considerably. Catalytic cleaning is probably the most efficient way of decreasing the environmental impacts of bio-fuel combustion. Several studies concerning catalytic purification of flue gases from bio-fuel combustion have been presented over the years. Several problems must be addressed when designing a catalyst for this application: Clogging problems from deposition of ashes and particulates in the catalyst Catalyst poisoning by sulphur, phosphorus, alkali metals etc. Catalyst fouling due to deposition of ashes and particulates A.E Ahlstriim-Silversand, C.U.L Odenbrand/Applied Catalysis A: General 153 (1997) 177-201 179 Catalyst overheating at high flue-gas temperatures Poor catalyst performance during start-up Small-scale combustion of bio-fuel is characterised by great variations con- cerning gas flows, temperatures and concentrations with respect to oxygen and pollutants. The emissions are especially severe during the initial stages of the combustion cycle when VOC and PAH are released and emitted [3]. During the final part of the combustion cycle the CO-emission increases as the temperature in the combustion zone decreases. To be able to clean the flue gases effectively with respect to VOC and PAH, the catalyst temperature must increase rapidly during the start-up phase. This implies a low thermal inertia of the catalyst. Most studies have been focused on monolith-type catalysts and the conversion of CO, VOC and PAH typically is above 80% [4-13]. The observed problems are associated with increased pressure drop due to catalyst clogging and decreased catalyst performance due to fouling and poisoning. In most cases precious metals, preferably Pt, have been used as active combustion catalyst. Precious metals have a high activity for the combustion of CO and hydrocarbons and a fair stability against poisoning with compounds present in flue gases from bio-fuel, e.g. sulphur and alkali metals. Even if precious metals have been demonstrated to give a high activity in the combustion of gases like CO and VOC, some metal oxides are superior in combusting condensable and solid compounds like tar and soot particulates [ 14,15]. The catalyst should therefore contain precious metals as well as metal oxides in order to be effective in the purification of flue gases from bio- fuel combustion. This study is focused on wire-mesh catalysts for the purification of flue gases. By covering a wire mesh with a porous ceramic layer through a modified thermal spray technique an active and durable catalyst can be produced. The surface area of the porous ceramic layer can be increased by an in-situ precipitation technique, through wash coating or through sol-treatment. The ceramic layer is finally covered with a catalytically active material, e.g. Pd, Pt or metal oxides. Wire-mesh catalysts combine the excellent mass and heat transfer performance of a pellet-type catalyst with the low pressure drop of a monolith. The effects of pore diffusion during combustion are relatively small due to the shell like design of the catalyst layer. Thus the catalyst efficiency is considerably improved compared with pellet or monolith catalysts. The effects of catalyst clogging and fouling can be handled as wire-mesh catalyst are easy to disassemble and to clean. Wire-mesh catalysts also offer a great flexibility with respect to dimensions which makes retrofit installations easier. The aim of this study is to examine thermally sprayed wire-mesh catalysts for the purification of flue gases with respect to CO and different hydrocarbons and to determine the effects of different catalyst characteristics, e.g. mesh number, catalyst surface area and content of active material. Catalyst preparation and characterisation 2.1.1. Thermal spraying Wire meshes (Kanthal AF, 8 to 20 Tayler mesh) were coated with a layer consisting of a mixture of alumina and polyamide through a modified thermal spray technique. The ceramic and polymer powders used during the spraying process were supplied by Sulzer-Metco. The polymer content of the alumina/ polyamide mixture was varied between 0 and 40 vol.%. The wire meshes were first blasted with alumina powder in order to remove fat and oxides from the metal surface. The alumina/polyamide mixture was then plasma-sprayed onto the surface of the wire meshes. The thickness of the ceramic layer was normally around 0.1 mm. The samples were finally fired at 1073 K for 2 h to combust the polymer content of the sprayed layer. Through this procedure, the ceramic layer obtained an open macro-porosity. The total pore volume was determined through a gravimetric procedure where the pores of the ceramic layer were filled with distilled water through conventional impregnation. Excess water was removed by blowing the samples with compressed air. The total pore volume was then determined by calculating the gain in weight following the water impregnation. The surface area of the as-sprayed ceramic layer was normally below 1 m2 g 1. It is necessary to increase the surface area of the ceramic layer by a factor 10 or more to be able to achieve an acceptable catalytic activity. 2.1.2. Methods of increasing the surface area By adding ceramic material with a high surface area to the thermally sprayed ceramic matrix, the surface area of the ceramic layer can be increased consider- ably. Additional ceramic material can be supplied in at least three ways: a) conventional wash coating, b) in-situ precipitation and c) through sol-treatment. Wash coating was performed with a slurry of Spheralite 531 P3 from ProCatalyse (specific surface area -- 115 m2 g-l, particle size -- 8-12 ~tm, composition -- 2 wt.% of La203/NdzO3 on "/-alumina). The resulting average thickness of the wash coated layer was normally around 20 ~tm. The adhesion of the wash coated layer to the thermally sprayed layer was fair due to the roughness of the surface. In-situ precipitation was performed through impregnating the thermally sprayed layer with a saturated solution of aluminium nitrate at room temperature. The samples were then subjected to ammonia vapour at room temperature whereupon A.E Ahlstr6m-Silversand, C.U.L Odenbrand/Applied Catalysis A: General 153 (1997) 177-201 181 aluminium hydroxide was precipitated in the pores of the thermally sprayed layer. The samples were then dried at 423 K for 2 h and finally fired at 873 K for 2 h. Sol-treatment was performed with an colloidal alumina-sol from Nyacol, containing 20 wt.% of solid matter with an average particle size of 50 nm. After the sol-treatment the samples were dried at 423 K for 2 h and finally fired at 873 K for 2h. It is also possible to obtain an as-sprayed ceramic layer with a relatively high surface area by deposition of another ceramic powder with a high surface area into the spray jet. If the deposition is performed close to the substrate surface the deposited powder is built into the matrix of the sprayed layer without excessive loss of the surface area. In these tests we added an amount corresponding to 0-40 wt.% of Spheralite 509D from ProCatalyse (7-alumina, specific surface area 326 me g-l) into the spray jet of the alumina drops. Specific areas of the ceramic layers were measured with an area meter (FlowSorb II from Micromeritics) through adsorption of nitrogen according to the one-point BET-method. The samples were de-gassed in a flow of dry nitrogen at 623 K for 16 h prior to the measurements. 2.1.3. Impregnation with active combustion catalyst The precious-metal catalysts were prepared through impregnation of the porous ceramic layer with aqueous solutions of precious metals (Pd and Pt). The solutions were prepared by dissolving pure metals in aqua regia and diluting these con- centrated solutions with distilled water to appropriate concentrations. Following the impregnation step excess solution was blown off with compressed air, where- upon the samples were dried at 393 K for 1 h and reduced in an atmosphere of 10 vol.% of hydrogen in nitrogen at 1073 K for 2 h. The samples where finally fired in air at 1073 K for 2 h. The relative amount of Pd in the metal mixture normally corresponded to 75 mol%. The total metal loading was 10 ~tmol m-2. The oxide catalysts were prepared by impregnating the samples with aqueous solutions of NH4VO3 (oxalic acid) and Cu(NO3)2. After impregnating with NH4VO3 (oxalic acid), the samples were dried (393 K for 1 h) and fired in air (873 K for 2 h). The samples were then impregnated with the Cu-solution and once again dried and fired. In some cases we doped the oxide-catalyst with precious metals through impregnation with diluted solutions of precious metals. The relative amount of V in the oxide catalyst was 90 mol%. This catalyst composition has previously been demonstrated to give a high activity in the combustion of soot -2 particulates [15]. The total metal loading corresponded to 10 ~tmol m All chemicals used during the catalyst preparation were of analytical grade. 2.2. Experimental procedure 2.3.1. Combustion of gases The combustion experiments were performed at different temperatures between 323 and 873 K and at different conditions with respect to gas flow and gas composition. The study includes combustion experiments with CO, ethylene, propylene, butadiene, ethanol, methanol, methane, benzene and terpenes (Alcro Beckers). The gas mixture was led through the catalyst and the conversion of the pollutant compounds as well as the selectivity for total oxidation was determined. A.F. The catalytically active wire meshes were coated with tar through a painting technique. The exact amount of tar added was determined gravimetrically. The tar-coated catalysts were then placed in the reactor whereupon a stream of air was led through it. The catalyst temperature was increased linearly with time (10 K min-~) and the production rate of CO, CO2 and HzO as well as the desorption of volatile tar components could be studied. The formation of combustion products versus the temperature gives a semi-quantitative picture of the catalyst activity. 2.3.3. Combustion of charcoal and soot particulates In these studies we used charcoal from hardwood, which was water grinded into a slurry. The slurry was painted onto the catalytically active wire meshes. Diesel soot was used during the studies concerning soot combustion. The soot has been thoroughly characterised with respect to physical and chemical char- acteristics in a previous study [16]. Also the soot/water-mixture was painted onto the catalytically active wire meshes. The combustion experiments were performed in the same way as described above for the combustion for tar. 3. Results 3.1. Modified thermal spray technique to increase the porosity of the ceramic layer Powders of alumina and polyamide (0-40 vol.%) were mixed into a homo- geneous mixture. The mixture was spray-deposited onto wire meshes of Kanthal AF with a plasma-spray equipment. The resulting polymer/ceramic layer was around 0.1 mm in thickness. The wire meshes where fired in air to burn off the polymer content whereby, the porosity of the ceramic layer was increased. The results show that the porosity of the ceramic layer was increased by a factor two or more through the addition of a polymer powder, as can be seen in Fig. 2. Without addition of the polymer powder the porosity of the ceramic layer was slightly above 10%. The porosity is linearly correlated to the volume fraction of polymer powder added. According to our results, the volume fraction of polymer powder added should not exceed 35 vol.%. Increasing the polymer content of the sprayed layer over this value will deteriorate its strength. 3.2. Discussion There are several problems associated with the purification of flue gases from small-scale combustion of bio-fuel. The transient behaviour of the combustion results in great variations in gas flows, temperatures and gas compositions during the course of the combustion. The demands concerning the pressure drop over the catalyst are tough as many stoves lack fans for forced convection. According to Rehnberg et al. the maximum acceptable pressure drop over the catalyst is between 10 and 20 Pa [4]. Catalysts based on pellets or ceramic fibres will give a too high pressure drop in most applications whereas monolith and wire mesh catalysts easily can meet the demands concerning the pressure drop. To combust deposits of charcoal, soot and tar the catalyst must be placed relatively close to the combustion zone. The catalyst should be able to with- stand temperatures in the region of 973-1073 K without excessive thermal deactivation. A.E Ahlstr6m-Silversand, C.U.L Odenbrand/Applied Catalysis A: General 153 (1997) 177-201 197 The flue gases contain a lot of different trace elements like sulphur, phosphorus, chlorine and alkaline metals. Most oxide catalysts are sensitive to these compounds whereas, precious metals have a fair resistance towards poisoning. According to Satterfield precious metals are only slightly and reversibly deactivated by sulphur [ 17]. Pt is however more stable towards sulphur poisoning than Pd, as indicated by Hoyos et al. [18]. At temperatures above 673 K the sulphate groups produced on the Pd-surface are decomposed and the activity is restored. The presence of chloride compounds are known to cause a significant decrease in activity for metal catalyst [19,20]. The chloride compounds are however normally removed under the influence of water formed during the combustion [20]. It is also possible to restore the activity through washing the catalyst with distilled water. Alkaline metals also can cause deactivation in several ways. The vapour pressures of alkali metals are very high at the combustion temperatures and are transported into the pores of the catalyst through gas phase diffusion. In addition to catalysts poisoning, fouling will occur due to the deposition of charcoal, soot and tar. Deposits of soot and tar will form dense layers on the catalyst surface which will result in an excessive increase in the resistance to mass transfer. These compounds can be combusted if the catalyst temperature gets high enough. Certain metal oxide catalysts effectively combust these compounds at temperatures prevailing in the flue gas channel during combustion. If the catalyst does not contain suitable active components or if the catalyst temperature is too low, the catalyst can be totally clogged by tar and soot, as demonstrated by Shelter et al. [13]. Monolith catalysts have been used in most studies concerning flue gas purifica- tion from bio-fuel combustion (e.g. [4-13]). To our knowledge wire mesh catalysts have never been studied in this application. There are several important aspects to take into consideration when choosing an appropriate catalyst design containing a carrier material and a catalytically active material: Thermal inertia Thermal shock resistance Efficiency of the active material Mass and heat transfer characteristics Pressure drop Possibilities of thermal sintering and catalyst poisoning Fouling by deposits of ash, charcoal, soot and tar residues Geometric flexibility Catalyst cost The weight/volume-ratio of a monolith catalysts is relatively high. Due to the poor mass and heat transfer characteristics in the channels of the monolith, the contact area between the gas and the catalyst must be increased, leading to an increased monolith volume and an increased weight. The weight/volume-ratio of a package of catalytically active wire meshes is lower and the mass and heat transfer 198 A.E Ahlstriim-Silversand, C.U.1. Odenbrand/Applied Catalysis A: General 153 (1997) 177-201 numbers are considerably higher (by a factor 5-10). As the catalyst normally works in the mass transfer controlled mode, the catalyst volume will be much smaller than the corresponding volume of the monolith. The combination of a small catalyst volume and high heat transfer numbers will lead to a low thermal inertia of the wire mesh catalyst. Monolith catalysts are more susceptible to cracking than wire mesh catalysts. The cracks often occurs during transient conditions with respect to the tempera- ture. The shell-like design of the catalytically active layer in combination with the high mass transfer numbers of the wire mesh catalyst provides an excellent utilisation of the active material. The catalyst efficiency is lower in a monolith catalyst due to the poorer mass transfer characteristics. The pressure drop over a package of catalytically wire meshes can easily meet the demands concerning a maximum pressure drop of 10-20 Pa. The low pressure drop can be attributed to the high porosity of the wire-mesh package (normally 70% or above) and to the relatively high ratio between the cross sectional area and the height. The wire-mesh catalyst is easy to disassemble in order to take away fouling components like ash- and charcoal-particles. A monolith catalyst is more difficult to clean mechanically. The geometric flexibility of the wire-mesh catalyst makes it suitable for retrofit installations. It is thus possible to adjust the geometric appearance of the wire-mesh catalyst in any way to fit it into a flue gas channel of arbitrary shape. Monolith catalysts do not offer the same possibilities. Consequently, installation of wire- mesh catalysts is expected to be easier and cheaper compared to installing monolith catalysts. The catalyst cost is not expected to be higher for a package of catalytically active wire-meshes than for the corresponding monolith catalyst. The mass-transfer characteristics of woven wire-mesh catalysts have been extensively studied before (e.g. [21]). In most cases, however, the studies have been focused on wire-mesh catalysts for the production of nitric acid. Wire-mesh catalysts are also used in the production of hydrogen cyanide and formaldehyde. In all cases the wire meshes consist of thin metal threads which are woven together. The specific surface area of these wire meshes is low and they can only be used to catalyse extremely fast reactions. Homogeneous wire meshes of precious metals should however be far too expensive in VOC-combustion. One way to reduce the catalyst cost is to deposit precious metals onto a surface of a cheaper material, e.g. steel, through an electro-chemical process. The problem is to get a sufficient adhesion between the metals and to prevent scaling. Again the specific surface area of such catalysts is very low. By dipping a wire mesh into a slurry of ceramic particles or a sol it is possible to add a ceramic layer to the metal surface. The adhesion between the metal and the ceramic material is however poor and the ceramic material will flake off, especially under the influence of vibrations. A.F. Ahlstrrm-Silversand, C.U.L Odenbrand/Applied Catalysis A: General 153 (1997) 177-201 199 Thermal spray-coating has been used in catalyst preparation before (e.g. [22]). In most cases standard settings of the spray equipment and standard powders have been used. Under such circumstances the porosity of the sprayed ceramic layer will be very low, normally 5% or below. The only way of increasing the surface area of a dense layer of this kind is through conventional wash coating. This method has the same drawbacks as presented above, i.e. the adhesion between the substrate and the wash coat is insufficient in most applications. By deliberately increasing the porosity of the sprayed layer through a modified spray technique we have demonstrated the possibilities of preparing an active and durable catalyst for the combustion of CO and hydrocarbons. Sol-treatment is a superior method of increasing the specific surface area of the as-sprayed ceramic layer. By repeating the sol-treatment the resulting specific surface area is accu- rately controllable. A catalytically active material is then added to the ceramic layer through a conventional impregnation procedure. The amount of catalytically active material needed is relatively low due to the shell-like structure of the ceramic layer. As expected, Pt-promoted Pd is very effective in the combustion of CO and gaseous hydrocarbons. The combustion is generally limited by the external mass transfer and only marginally by effects of pore-diffusion. The activity of the catalyst is influenced by the specific surface area and the loading of catalytically active material. The effects of the catalyst activity are however observable only in the reaction controlled mode. In the mass transfer controlled mode the conversion is affected by the number of wire meshes in series and the mesh number. Precious metals lack the ability to combust solid and condensable hydrocarbons effectively. This observation is partly attributed to the poor wetting characteristics of precious metals. Certain metal oxides, and especially so a mixture between V205 and CuO, have proven to be very effective in combusting solid and condensable hydrocarbons. The mixed oxide has a low melting point and therefore also an appreciable structural mobility at the reaction temperature and this promotes the wetting characteristics. The wire-mesh approach also offers unique possibilities of constructing sandwich catalysts. It is thus possible to place a couple of metal oxide covered wire meshes in front of the package of wire meshes containing precious metals. The solid and condensable matter could be trapped and combusted in the oxide-containing wire meshes, whereas, CO and gaseous hydrocarbons are combusted in the wire meshes containing precious metals. We intend to study the problems of deactivation thoroughly in a separate study. This study will include the effects of thermal deactivation, poisoning and fouling. 5. Catalytically active wire meshes were used to combust different pollutants present in flue gases from bio-fuel combustion, e.g. CO, propylene, terpenes and tar. Alumina was spray-deposited onto wire meshes of Kanthal AF (8–20 Tayler mesh) with a plasma spray equipment. The specific surface area of the ceramic layer was increased through wash coating, in-situ precipitation or sol-treatment. The catalytically active materials consisted of precious metals ( Pd Pt ) or metal oxides ( V2O5 CuO ) and were added to the ceramic matrix through an impregnation technique. The combustion was in most cases severely limited by external mass transfer. The effects of the specific surface area and the loading of catalytically active material were only significant in the reaction controlled domain. In the mass transfer controlled domain the conversion was affected only by the flow conditions and the external surface area of the wire meshes. CO and most hydrocarbons were effectively combusted at temperatures below 773 on a Pd Pt -catalyst . The catalyst performance was not affected by the presence of water vapour or carbon dioxide or by low oxygen concentrations. Similar combustion experiments were performed with a commercial monolith and it can be concluded that the performance of the catalytically active wire meshes in the mass-transfer controlled domain was superior. Tar-residues, soot particulates and charcoal particles were effectively combusted over a Pd Pt -doped oxide-catalyst ( V2O5 CuO ).
